docs.title: Divine Steam
docs.text:
Welcome to the Divine Steam website. Here you'll be able to find everything concerning the campaign. Susceptible to changes.

This campaign used to be named Divine Steam 2, as it was the second campaign carrying the Divine Steam title. It has now been chosen to rename the older campaign to Divine Steam Legacy

docs.title: Class home
docs.text: Welcome to the Divine Steam classes. Below are a list of classes allowed from source material. And Additional (sub)classes written for Divine Steam

docs.title: Source Material
docs.text:
All these are from the 2024 PHB & 2025 Eberron Subclasses are still being chosen

  • Barbarian
  • Fighter
  • Monk
  • Rogue
  • Articifer

docs.title: Divine Steam specific classes
docs.text: • Magician

docs.title: Chirurgy
docs.text: Chirurgy is the study of medicine through a magical lens. Magicians in this college learn how to use their magic to better heal others and improve their lives by strengthening the aetheric patterns that define them. As such, chirurgeons are highly sought after and well-paid to keep their patients healthy beyond the limitations of modern medicine.

docs.title: Expert Healer
docs.text: When you take this archetype at 3rd level, your concentration in remedial magic makes your healing spells more potent. Whenever you cast a spell that restores Hit Points to a creature, including yourself, the creature regains additional Hit Points equal to 2 + the spell’s Appetance cost up to their Hit Point maximum.

docs.title: Self Preservation
docs.text:
Starting at 7th level, you have either learned to trick the magical energy within creatures into thinking it’s invulnerable or you apply a pain numbing medicine.

When you touch a creature, including yourself, you can give them Resistance to Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing Damage for one minute. After the minute has ended, the creature loses one Hit Die. If the creature had no more Hit Dice, they instead gain a level of Exhaustion.

docs.title: Stimulate Healing
docs.text: Starting at 11th level, you learn how to make creatures reweave their own Appetance to heal themselves. As an Action, you can touch a creature, and they may immediately spend their Hit Dice to heal themselves. If they roll a 1 on a Hit Die, they can choose to reroll and must use the new roll.

docs.title: Pure Pattern
docs.text: Starting at 15th level, you’ve strengthened your own Appetance so much so that it is difficult to alter. You are immune to disease and poison, you have Resistance to Poison Damage, and you have Advantage on any Saving Throws against being Blinded or Deafened.

docs.title: Master Chirurgeon
docs.text: Starting at 18th level, your healing power is so great that you can maximise the effect of your spells. Whenever you cast a spell that requires you to roll dice to determine Hit Points restored, you may instead receive the maximum amount possible.

docs.title: Escapist
docs.text: The Escapist is a master of misdirection, agility, and theatrical flair. Their magic and skill are focused on slipping free from danger, evading attacks, and turning escape into performance. Every gesture, step, and flick of the wrist is calculated to confound opponents and control the battlefield, making them unpredictable and elusive. Through rigorous training, quick thinking, and minor thaumaturgy, Escapists turn every threat into an opportunity to amaze, disappear, or vanish into safety—leaving their foes bewildered and their audience captivated.

docs.title: Slip through
docs.text:
At 3rd level, you have learned to move like water through a crowd, a battlefield, or a trap-laden dungeon.

As a bonus action, you can spend 1 Appetance to move up to half your speed. During this movement:

  • You can move through creatures’ spaces as if they were difficult terrain.

  • You have advantage on Dexterity (Acrobatics) or Strength (Athletics) checks to escape restraints, grapple, or squeeze through tight spaces.

  • Any creature that attempts to make an opportunity attack against you during this movement does so with disadvantage.

docs.title: Cloak Flourish
docs.text:
At 7th level when a creature you can see hits you with an attack, you may use your reaction and spend 1 Appetance to whip your cloak in a burst of illusion.

You may reduce the damage you take by 1d6 + your spellcasting ability modifier. In addition you become invisible you may immediately move up to 10 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.

You have a number of uses equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and regain all uses on a Long Rest.

docs.title: Magician
docs.text:
The combination of spectacle and magic is what the modern day wizard, sorcerer and bard have become. The preserved knowledge of families about the Arcane is what allows somebody's inherent energy come to fruition. By shaping a spell and exerting it within the art of Thaumaturgy, the Magician makes the impossible possible. Wheter that be through the shock of healing wounds at an instant, or through the comedic and whimsical displays of dissapearance.

Though the era of mages regrowing limbs and teleporting across realms is over, mordern magicians can still put their power to use. Kowledge on the supernaturnal and occult have made Magicians believe that they are nescessary to keep the world safe, while also keeping the masses entertained.

The art of Thaumaturgy requires rumorous training to harness. Most Magicians must start training from a young age to truly harness. This costs time and money, and thus, the role of Magician is often placed upon nobles.

docs.title: Magician Features
docs.text: As a Magician your Primry Ability Score is either Intelligence or Charisma (you may choose one), and you have the following Class Features:

docs.title: Hit Points
docs.text: Hit Dice: 1d6 per Magician level Hit Points at first level: 6 + your Constitution Bonus Hit Points at higher levels: 1d6 or 4 + your Constitution Bonus. If you decide to roll your hit dice and you roll lower than a 3, you count as having rolled a 3.

docs.title: Proficiencies
docs.text: Armour: Light Armour Weapons: Simple Weapons, Reinforced Canes (hidden 1d8 or 1d10 two-handed), Swordstick (hidden Shortsword) Tools: None Saving Throws: Intelligince, Charisma Skills: Choose 3 from Sleight of Hand, Arcana, History, Investigation, Medicine, Deception, Performance

docs.title: Thaumaturgy
docs.text: You are trained in the magical art of Thaumaturgy. You’ve turned your body into a conduit for magic though spectacle. You draw magical energy from your surroundigs and reshape it into something new. The energy; also known as Appetance, is used to create such spells and returns to you once their power has been unleashed.

docs.title: Cantrips
docs.text: At 1st level, you know three cantrips of your choice from the Magician spell list. You learn additional Magician cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the *Magician table.

docs.title: Spells
docs.text:
You have a pool of Appetance equal to your Level. You spend Appetance from this pool whenever you wish to cast a spell

You learn two spells at 1st level from the Magician spell list. Since magic has been lost in the world, you are not able to learn any spells whenever you level up. To acquire more spells, you must acquire them through scrolls, passed on knowledge, or rugirous observation within the world.

You can cast any spell that you know at any time, as long as you have sufficient Appetance remaining. You regain all spent Appetance when you finish a Long Rest.

docs.title: Spellcasting Ability
docs.text:
Intelligence or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Magician spells. You use your Intelligence or Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence or Charisma Bonus when setting the Saving Throw DC for a spell you cast and when making an Attack Roll with one.

Spell Save DC = 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + your Intelligence or Charisma Bonus Spell atack Bonus = your your Proficiency Bonus + your Intelligence or Charisma Bonus

docs.title: Force of Will
docs.text:
You can spend your body’s energy to provide more Appetance when necessary.

In addition you may spend Hit Dice and accept levels of Exhaustion if you do not have enough Appetance to cast a spell. You may only spend Hit Dice equal to half the spells level rounded up, while the rest of the spell must be fueled with levels of Exhaustion. For example: With 1 Appetance, casting a 4th level spell will cost 1 Appetance, 2 Hit Dice and 1 Exhaustion. If this effect causes you to become so exhausted that you will die, then you may still act for the remainder of your turn before dying, enabling you to cast the spell that drained you.

docs.title: The Show Must Go On
docs.text: Starting at 2nd level, your basic training as a Magician allows you to recuperate faster than most. Whenever you take at least one level of Exhaustion from the Force of Will ability, you may remove 1 level of Exhaustion on a Short Rest and 2 on a Long Rest.

docs.title: Magician College
docs.text: Starting at 3rd level, you choose a thaumaturgical college to focus your magical studies. Choose from Chirurgy, Manipulator and Escapist. Your archetype grants you features at 3rd, 7th, 11th, 15th, and 18th level.

docs.title: Ability Score Improvement
docs.text: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. You may also choose a feat instead.

docs.title: Arcane Flourish
docs.text:
At 6th level, your mastery of magical spectacle allows you to create a performance through the manipulation of the world. As an Action you can perform a Flourish, a dramatic, deliberate act that reshapes how the spell manifests.

A Flourish grants one temporary magical effect of your choice:

  • Emanating Magic. The area around you shimmers with magical energy. Allies within 10 feet of you gain a bonus to one ability check of your choice until your next turn equal to your proficiency bonus.

  • Kinetic Emphasis. You can subtly push or pull a creature, object, or hazard up to 10 feet as part of the Flourish. If the creature is not willing it must make a Strength Saving Throw against your Spell Save DC to resist being pushed or pulled.

  • Dramatic Presence. The Flourish leaves a lasting impression. Any creature that sees it may be awed or intimidated. The DM can grant a reaction bonus on a Persuasion, Intimidation, or Deception check at the start of their next turn.

You have a number of uses equal to your Spellcasting Ability Modifier.

docs.title: Sustained Appetance
docs.text:
At 10th level, your magical conduit has stabilized.

When you roll initiative and have no Appetance remaining, you regain Appetance equal to your spellcasting ability modifier (minimum of 1). Additionally, once per Short Rest, when you cast a spell using Force of Will, you may choose to reduce the total Exhaustion cost of that casting by 1.
